{{for|the issue in the US|List of cases of police brutality in the United States}} This list compiles incidents of [[police brutality]] that have garnered significant media and/or historical attention. <!-- Do not add new names or items to this list without first verifying the information through a reliable neutral source and providing a reference to it. Please add new entries in chronological order. -->
==2010âpresent==
*July 09, 2011 The [[United Nations]] human rights office expressed disappointment on the use of excessive force<ref>{{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Malaysia: UN rights office voices concern about recent crackdown on protesters | newspaper = UN News Center | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2011-7-12 | url = http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=39011&Cr=Malaysia&Cr1= | accessdate = 2011-7-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Malaysia âoverreacts with mass arrestsâ | newspaper = The Jakarta Post | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2011-7-12 | url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/07/12/malaysia-âoverreacts-with-mass-arrestsâ.html | accessdate = 2011-7-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = UN rights disappointed by Malaysian police crackdown | newspaper = The Straits Times | location = Singapore | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2011-7-12 | url = http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_689816.html | accessdate = 2011-7-13}}</ref> by the police against peaceful protestors in the [[Bersih 2.0 rally]], which organised by the Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections ([[Bersih]]) calling for electoral reform in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]]. *June 06, 2011 22-year-old Martin Neshkovski was beaten to death by Igor Spasov, a member of the special police unit Tigers, in the center of [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia]] during the celebration of the ruling partyâs VMRO-DPMNE election victory, supposedly because he wanted to climb on stage and congratulate the Prime Minister [[Nikola Gruevski]] personally. After an unsuccessful attempt by the Macedonian institutions to cover up the murder<ref>{{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Marching Against Police Brutality in Macedonia | newspaper = Al Jazeera English | location = Washington DC | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2011-6-13 | url = http://stream.aljazeera.com/story/macedonia | accessdate = 2011-6-17}}</ref>, which was followed by two day demonstrations in Skopje, Spasov admitted the murder. Protesters kept on protesting every day starting at 18.00h demanding bigger control over special police unit members and political and moral responsibility a.k.a resignation of the Minister of Interior, Gordana Jankuloska, and the spokesman of the Ministry of Interior, Ivo Koteski. *Dec 27, 2010 A 24-year old man was brought to the police station in [[Ã lesund]] for protective custody after drunk and disorderly conduct. While still in handcuffs, he was beaten by a senior police officer. While being brought to a holding cell he was beaten and subjected to strangulating force by the same officer. The incident was fully taped by the stations own surveillance cameras. In sept 2011, the officer was convicted to 30 days in prison and a fine of 10.000 NOK, but were allowed to keep his position as a police officer. *Jan 22, 2010. Yao Wei Wu was beaten by officers from [[Vancouver Police Department]] who knocked on the wrong door while investigating a report of a violent domestic dispute.<ref> {{Cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Vancouver police apologize after man beaten | newspaper = CBC News | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2010-1-22 | url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2010/01/21/bc-vpd-alleged-assault-yao-wei-wu.html | accessdate = 2010-6-21}}</ref> Speaking through a translator, Yao Wei Wu told CBC News that as soon as he opened the door the officers pulled him out of the house and beat him.
==2000â2009== * April 1, 2009. Passing through the G20 summit protests in London, [[Death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]] was struck in the back of his legs and pushed to the ground by a police constable with the [[Territorial Support Group]] in South London. He died soon afterwards. The initial police statement said that police had been alerted that a man had collapsed, and were attacked by "a number of missiles" as they tried to save his life.<ref Name="GuardianArticle">{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2009/apr/08/ian-tomlinson-g20-death-official-police-account | publisher=The Guardian | title=G20 fatality: How police view of Ian Tomlinson death changed | date=8 April 2009 | location=London | accessdate=2010-05-08}}</ref> Several videos from citizen passersby surfaced about one week after the incident and sparked public outcry. The officer has been interviewed on suspicion of manslaughter.<ref name=ManslaughterInterview>{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2009/apr/17/ian-tomlinson-g20-protest-coroner | author=Paul Lewis | publisher=The Guardian | title=Tomlinson officer questioned on suspicion of manslaughter | date=17 April 2009 | location=London}}</ref> * December 6, 2008. 15-year-old Alexandros Grigoropoulos was [[2008 Greek riots|shot dead]] by police officer Epaminondas Korkoneas shortly after 9 p.m. in the [[Exarcheia]] district of [[Athens, Greece]]. Demonstrations and riots erupted throughout Athens almost immediately after the shooting, sparking weeks of civil unrest and workplace and university occupations throughout [[Greece]] and beyond.<ref>{{cite web |title=Two indicted over teen shooting |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_politics_100033_13/06/2009_108067 |publisher=[[Kathimerini]] |date=June 13, 2009 |accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> *September 7, [[2006]]. Eugene Ejike Obiora, a Nigerian-Norwegian student was killed during an arrest where Obiora had behaved aggressively toward personnel at the social services office in [[Trondheim]]. Obiora died enroute to a hospital after police officer Trond Volden strangled him in the subsequent struggle. Volden and three other officers were processed for use of force but were cleared by the police investigators and the chief prosecutor. Volden had earlier been videotaped, but cleared of charges, when harassing and strangling a Ghani-Norwegian woman in 1999.[http://www.adressa.no/nyheter/trondheim/article718331.ece][http://wwwc.aftonbladet.se/kvinna/0004/03/sophia.html] *July [[2006]]. Footage shown at her trial showed 19âyearâold Toni Comer being repeatedly punched, kicked and dragged to a waiting police van in Sheffield in 2006.<ref>[http://www.sheffieldtoday.net/viewarticle.aspx?articleid=2109819&sectionid=6316 Video of beating made me feel sick - Toni Comer]</ref>
==1990â1999== [[Image:Randdogs030198.jpg|right|200px|thumb|January 3, [[1998]]: Policemen from the North East Rand Dog Unit set their dogs on three Mozambican immigrants]] *January 3, [[1998]]. Six policemen from the North East Rand Dog Unit set their [[Police dog|dogs]] on three suspected [[Illegal immigration|illegal immigrant]]s, allowing the animals to attack the three men as the officers shouted racial insults. The incident was caught on video and televised nationally by the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]] on Nov. 7, [[2000]], causing widespread outrage. All six policemen were ultimately sentenced to jail terms of between four and five years each.<ref>{{cite news | title = Police jailed over dog attack |url = http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/africa/11/29/police.court/index.html | publisher = CNN | author = CNN News | date = 2001-11-29 | accessdate = 2007-08-30 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Racist, barbaric incidnt leaves SA shellshocked |url = http://www.queensu.ca/samp/migrationresources/xenophobia/articles/racist.htm | publisher = Zimbabwe Mirror | author = Tendai Dumbutshena | date = 2000-11-17 | accessdate = 2007-08-30 }}</ref> *September 7, [[1995]]. [[Dudley George]], an [[Ojibwa]] protestor, was shot and killed by [[Ontario Provincial Police]] Sergeant Kenneth Deane near [[Ipperwash Provincial Park]] in [[Ontario]] in [[1995]] during the [[Ipperwash Crisis]]. Sergeant Deane was later convicted of [[criminal negligence]] causing death.<ref>Peter Edwards, [[One Dead Indian]]. Toronto: Stoddart Publishing Co. Ltd., 2001. pp.158-198</ref> ==Before 1990== *[[1977]]. [[Steve Biko]] is widely believed to have been killed by police as a result of anti-[[South Africa under apartheid|apartheid]] demonstrations in [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sahistory.org.za/pages/people/bios/biko-s.htm | title = Stephen Bantu Biko | work = South African History Online | accessdate = 2007-12-03}}</ref> *14â15 August 1969: During the [[1969 Northern Ireland riots]], the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] (RUC) shot dead five Catholic civilians and opened-fire on crowds of Irish nationalist protesters. *13 July 1969 in [[Dungiven]], [[Northern Ireland]]. Catholic civilian Francis McCloskey (67) was beaten with batons by [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] (RUC) officers during street disturbances and died of his injuries the following day. He is sometimes deemed to be the first death of "[[The Troubles]]".<ref>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch69.htm#Jul Chronology of the Conflict: July 1969], [[Conflict Archive on the Internet]]</ref> *19 April 1969 in [[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]]. During rioting between Irish nationalists and the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] (RUC), RUC officers broke into the home of Catholic civilian Samuel Devenny (42), who was not involved in the riots. The officers kicked Devenny and beat him ferociously with batons. His young daughter (who was recovering from [[surgery]]) and a family friend were beaten unconscious. His older daughter and son were also attacked. It is believed that the attack led to Devenny's death on 17 July 1969.<ref>[http://www.policeombudsman.org/publicationsuploads/Devenny-report.pdf Findings on Devenny investigation], [[Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland]]</ref> *17 October 1961. The [[National Police (France)|French police]] attacked a large demonstration of unarmed and peaceful protesters of [[Algeria]]n origin, killing between 70 and 200 (numbers are uncertain, partly because many were drowned after being thrown into the [[Seine]] with their hands tied), in the [[Paris massacre of 1961]]. *21 March 1960. South African police shot at a crowd of black anti-apartheid protesters, killing 69 and injuring over 180 in what became known as the [[Sharpeville massacre]]. Evidence showed that the police continued firing even when the crowd had turned to run, and the majority of those killed and wounded were shot in the back. The [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] later concluded that the police actions constituted "gross human rights violations in that excessive force was unnecessarily used to stop a gathering of unarmed people." (see [[Sharpeville massacre]] article for sourcing). *01 April 1922: The [[Arnon Street killings]] in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]]. Ten officers of the [[Ulster Special Constabulary]] (USC) broke into a number of [[Irish Catholic]]-owned homes and killed six Catholic civilians (including a child). This was believed to have been a reprisal for the [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]]'s killing of a policeman in the area. *24 March 1922: The [[McMahon murders]] in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Officers of the Ulster Special Constabulary (USC) broke into a house owned by an Irish Catholic family and shot all eight males inside. Six were killed. It is believed to have been a reprisal for the IRA's killing of two policemen the day before. *21 November 1920: The [[Bloody Sunday (1920)#Afternoon|Croke Park massacre]] in [[Dublin]], Ireland. [[Royal Irish Constabulary]] (RIC) officers opened-fire on civilians who were watching a [[Gaelic football]] match in [[Croke Park]]; 14 were killed and 60â70 wounded. The attack was believed to be revenge for an IRA assassination operation earlier in the day. *22 September 1920: In reprisal for [[Rineen Ambush|an ambush]] by the IRA, Royal Irish Constabulary (RIC) officers killed 5 civilians and burnt 16 houses/shops in west [[County Clare]], Ireland.
==Pending investigations== The investigations into these cases have not been completed. Parties involved in each case may or may not be exonerated by the investigation.
*62 protesters were hospitalized (including three comatose) after a brutal night-time raid on the Diaz school in [[Genoa]] where protesters were bedding down during the [[27th G8 summit]]. In an ongoing trial (expected to conclude in 2008), twenty-eight Italian police officers are indicted for grievous bodily harm, planting evidence and wrongful arrest. A further 45 state officials, including police officers, prison guards, and doctors, are charged with physically and mentally abusing demonstrators and journalists held in a detention centre in the nearby town of [[Bolzaneto]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Trial forces Italy to relive shocking police brutality | url = http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article318852.ece | publisher = The Independent |date= 2005-10-12 | accessdate = 2007-08-05 | location=London | first=Peter | last=Popham}}</ref>
*October 14, 2007. [[Robert DziekaÅski Taser incident|Robert DziekaÅski]], a Polish immigrant arriving at the [[Vancouver International Airport]], died after being [[taser]]ed multiple times and four members of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) crowded on top of DziekaÅski. "The 40-year-old Dziekanski had been at the airport for about 10 hours and, unable to speak English, became confused and agitated while waiting for his mother to meet him."<ref>{{cite news | title =RCMP to review Taser policy in wake of airport death: commissioner |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2007/11/17/rcmp-tasers.html | publisher = CBC | date = 2007-11-17 | accessdate = 2007-11-18 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Taser video shows RCMP shocked immigrant within 25 seconds of their arrival |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2007/11/14/bc-taservideo.html | publisher = CBC | date = 2007-11-15 | accessdate = 2007-11-18 }}</ref>
*[[Death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]], a bystander to the [[2009 G-20 London summit protests]] on 1 April 2009, was pushed to the ground and beaten by a police officer. He later died of disputed causes.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= Paul Lewis |authorlink= | title=Video reveals G20 police assault on man who died | date=7 April 2009 | publisher= | url =http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2009/apr/07/video-g20-police-assault | work =[[The Guardian]] | pages = | accessdate = 7 April 2009 | location=London}}</ref> The case is being investigated by the [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7986192.stm|title=Police watchdog probing G20 death |date=6 April 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-04-08}}</ref>
